comments.content: Secret: neutralization gives water + salt. The salt depends on the acid/base ions.

comments.content: Mistake to avoid: balancing H and OH to form H2O, then combine remaining ions to make salt.

reels.video_prompt: 12s energetic Gen-Z style reel: Title card 0.5s 'Neutralization in 12s' (fast glitch). Scene 1 (2s): Two characters (actor A = 'H+' in red jacket, actor B = 'OH-' in blue hoodie) meet dramatically under neon lights; quick voiceover line: 'When H+ meets OH-...'. Scene 2 (3s): They high-five and a slow-motion splash becomes a water droplet; voiceover: 'they become H2O â€” neutralized!' Add a quick onscreen visual: molecular icons (H+, OH-, water) popping into frame. Scene 3 (3s): Cut to a skateboarder cruising past holding a label 'Na+' and a friend holding 'Cl-'; voiceover: 'Leftovers? The spectator ions form a salt: NaCl.' Add quick visual of salt shaker labeled NaCl falling in slow-mo. Scene 4 (2s): Quick comedic beat where a tiny pH strip flips from low to 7 with sparkles; voiceover: 'pH -> 7 (if ideal)'. Ending (1.5s): Big text flash 'Water + Salt. Big chemistry energy.' Music: hyperpop beat, snappy cuts, occasional record-scratch sound. Include quick captions for accessibility: callouts 'H+ + OH- â†’ H2O' and 'Salt formed from spectator ions'. Make it funny and chaotic but scientifically accurate.

reels.video_prompt: 12s fast-cut reel: Start with title card 'Complete vs Incomplete Combustion' (0.5s). Scene 1 (3s): Show two burners side-by-side â€” left with a clean blue flame (complete), right with smoky yellow flame (incomplete). Voiceover: 'Blue flame = plenty O2 â†’ CO2 + H2O. Yellow smoke = not enough O2 â†’ CO, soot.' Add quick on-screen pop-ups: 'CO2 âœ”ï¸', 'CO âš ï¸', 'soot = C'. Scene 2 (4s): Short comedic sketch: three characters â€” 'Fuel' (dude in leather), 'O2' (two dancers), and 'Exhaust' (a dramatic narrator). The dancers try to reach the fuel; if both are there, they cheer and produce CO2 confetti; if only one arrives, someone coughs (CO). Insert 0.5s skateboard cameo where a skateboarder rolls through carrying a CO detector that beeps. Scene 3 (3s): Quick practical visual: glowing buoyant flames vs smoky lamp flame next to carbon monoxide warning icon. Ending (1.5s): 'Complete = CO2 + H2O; Incomplete = CO, C, less energy' with hyperpop beat. Include captions: 'Balance O2 to avoid CO' and 'CO is toxic â€” ventilate'. Make it punchy, slightly absurd, and memorable.

posts.title: Common polyatomic ions â€” cheat sheet
posts.author: ionguide

comments.author: shortcut_sam
comments.content: This is exactly the list I needed for Chem 101. Save it!

comments.author: confused_carla
comments.content: Why does sulfate have -2 while nitrate is -1? I keep mixing them up.

comments.author: explain_it_eli
comments.content: Quick: look at total valence electrons and how many oxygens â€” common ions follow stable electron counts, memorize the list then practice.

comments.author: meme_mol
comments.content: Me: *memorizes charges* Also me: instantly forgets when test day arrives ğŸ˜©

slides.content: Common ions: nitrate NO3- , nitrite NO2- , sulfate SO4^2- , sulfite SO3^2-, carbonate CO3^2-, bicarbonate HCO3- , ammonium NH4+ , hydroxide OH-.
Quick pattern: oxyanions with one more O often have same charge (NO2- vs NO3- both -1). Sulfate and sulfite both -2.
Memorize 6â€“8 common ions: OH-, NO3-, SO4^2-, CO3^2-, HCO3-, NH4+. Use them for naming and reactions.
Tip: Many salts are just metal + polyatomic ion e.g., NaNO3, CaCO3, (NH4)2SO4.

posts.title: Nitrate vs nitrite â€” what's different?
posts.author: oxy_friend

comments.author: tiny_titrat
comments.content: One O difference. Both -1. Nitrite = NO2-, nitrate = NO3-. Simple but slippery.

comments.author: sassy_sam
comments.content: I thought nitrite had -2 charge for a hot second. brain.exe crashed

comments.author: pro_tip_ron
comments.content: Sometimes in naming: -ite has fewer oxygens than -ate. Handy mnemonic.

comments.author: random_reaction
comments.content: this post slapped, snackable facts â™¥ï¸

slides.content: NO2- (nitrite): 2 oxygens, -1 charge. NO3- (nitrate): 3 oxygens, -1 charge.
Use the '-ite' vs '-ate' pattern: -ite = fewer oxygens, -ate = more oxygens.
Both behave similarly in salts (e.g., NaNO2, NaNO3) but differ in reactivity (nitrate often more stable).

comments.author: sea_salt
comments.content: Is bicarbonate just carbonate + H? yes, basically HCO3- comes from adding H+ to CO3^2-.

comments.author: acid_attack
comments.content: My teacher made a pun about 'bicarb saving the day' and now I remember it.

comments.author: buffer_bae
comments.content: Common confusion: HCO3- is amphiprotic â€” can act as acid or base depending on conditions.

comments.author: mischief_molly
comments.content: baking soda flexing in the comments ğŸ§

slides.content: Carbonate CO3^2- and bicarbonate HCO3- are related: H+ + CO3^2- â†’ HCO3-.
Bicarbonate acts as a buffer in blood: it can accept or donate H+ to stabilize pH.
Common salts: CaCO3 (limestone), NaHCO3 (baking soda). Names reflect ions present.

posts.title: Arrhenius vs Bronsted-Lowry â€” quick compare
posts.author: theory_snap

comments.author: philosopher_of_ph
comments.content: Arrhenius = H+/OH- in water only. Bronsted = proton donor/acceptor (broader).

comments.author: nitpick_nora
comments.content: People forget Arrhenius requires aqueous solutions â€” thatâ€™s the main limitation.

comments.author: meme_master
comments.content: Arrhenius: 'I only operate in water' Bronsted: 'I travel the world' ğŸ˜‚

slides.content: Arrhenius acid: produces H+ in water. Arrhenius base: produces OH- in water.
Bronsted-Lowry acid: proton (H+) donor. Base: proton acceptor. Works beyond aqueous systems.
Pick Bronsted-Lowry when asked about conjugate acids/bases; Arrhenius is fine for simple aqueous problems.

comments.author: titratation_tom
comments.content: Key confusion: pKa is about acid strength, not the same as pH. pH is solution property.

comments.author: quick_calc
comments.content: If pH < pKa, acid is mostly protonated; if pH > pKa, deprotonated. Use Henderson-Hasselbalch.

comments.author: silly_sam
comments.content: pH and pKa walk into a bar... Kb walks out. (I tried.)

slides.content: pH = -log[H+]. Lower pH = more acidic.
pKa indicates acid strength: lower pKa = stronger acid (more willing to donate H+).
Use Henderson-Hasselbalch: pH = pKa + log([A-]/[HA]) for buffer calculations.

comments.author: lab_noob
comments.content: Wait so the spectator ions don't change? I thought everything reacted.

comments.author: clear_comment
comments.content: Right â€” H+ and OH- make water. Na+ and Cl- are spectators and form the salt NaCl in solution.

comments.author: meme_maj
comments.content: The salt is the afterparty for spectator ions. they just vibeeeee ğŸ”¥

slides.content: Equation: HCl (aq) + NaOH (aq) â†’ NaCl (aq) + H2O (l).
Neutralization = acid H+ + base OH- â†’ water. Spectator ions form salt.
Net ionic: H+ + OH- â†’ H2O. Net ionic removes spectator ions.

comments.author: panic_pat
comments.content: Ugh balancing O2 always trips me up. whyyyyy

comments.author: method_maya
comments.content: Steps: balance C, then H, then O. If O odd, multiply to make even. Saved my exam once.

comments.author: flame_fran
comments.content: Pro tip: For CxHy + O2 â†’ CO2 + H2O, count O from CO2 and H2O, then divide by 2 for O2.

comments.author: meme_chemist
comments.content: Balance O2 like you're solving a sudoku. except hotter.

slides.content: General: CxHy + O2 â†’ x CO2 + (y/2) H2O. Balance C and H first, then O2 last.
If (y/2) is fractional, multiply whole equation by 2 to clear fractions.
Complete combustion: products CO2 + H2O (with enough O2). Incomplete can give CO or C (soot).

images.image_prompt: clean flat infographic diagram showing the carbonate-bicarbonate equilibrium: CO3^2- â†” HCO3- â†” H2CO3 with arrows, pH ranges indicated (basic â†’ carbonate, neutral â†’ bicarbonate, acidic â†’ carbonic acid), soft pastel palette, minimal text, clear molecular icons, vector style
images.description: Diagram showing carbonate (CO3^2-), bicarbonate (HCO3-), and carbonic acid (H2CO3) with arrows indicating equilibrium and approximate pH ranges where each form dominates.
images.caption: Carbonate and bicarbonate are in equilibrium: CO3^2- + H+ â‡Œ HCO3- and HCO3- + H+ â‡Œ H2CO3. Bicarbonate is often the dominant species near physiological pH.

images.image_prompt: cartoon-style meme image: a party scene where H+ and OH- are doing a dramatic slow-mo handshake in the center while Na+ and Cl- stand to the side holding chips labeled 'spectator ions'; bright colors, exaggerated expressions, minimal text
images.description: Cartoon meme showing H+ and OH- forming water in the center, while Na+ and Cl- watch from the side as spectator ions.
images.caption: In neutralization, spectator ions (like Na+ and Cl-) don't participate in the net ionic reaction â€” they simply remain in solution as the salt.
